# _It 's Complicated_ (film)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

It's Complicated  
---

_**It 's Complicated**_ is a 2009 American [romantic comedy
film](/wiki/Romantic_comedy_film "Romantic comedy film") written and directed
by [Nancy Meyers](/wiki/Nancy_Meyers "Nancy Meyers").[4] It stars [Meryl
Streep](/wiki/Meryl_Streep "Meryl Streep")[4] as a successful bakery owner and
single mother of three who starts a secret affair with her former husband,
played by [Alec Baldwin](/wiki/Alec_Baldwin "Alec Baldwin"),[4] ten years
after their divorce – only to find herself drawn to another man: her architect
Adam (portrayed by [Steve Martin](/wiki/Steve_Martin "Steve Martin")).[4] The
film also features supporting performances by [Lake Bell](/wiki/Lake_Bell
"Lake Bell"), [Hunter Parrish](/wiki/Hunter_Parrish "Hunter Parrish"), [Zoe
Kazan](/wiki/Zoe_Kazan "Zoe Kazan"), [John Krasinski](/wiki/John_Krasinski
"John Krasinski"), [Mary Kay Place](/wiki/Mary_Kay_Place "Mary Kay Place"),
[Robert Curtis Brown](/wiki/Robert_Curtis_Brown "Robert Curtis Brown") and
[Rita Wilson](/wiki/Rita_Wilson "Rita Wilson"), among others.[4][5]

The film was met with average reviews from critics, who praised the acting of
its ensemble cast but declared its story rather predictable. It became another
commercial hit for Meyers, however, upon its [Christmas
Day](/wiki/Christmas_Day "Christmas Day") 2009 opening release in the United
States and Canada. It played well through the holidays and in to January 2010,
ultimately closing on April 1 with $112.7 million. Worldwide, _It 's
Complicated_ eventually grossed $219.1 million, and surpassed _[The
Holiday](/wiki/The_Holiday "The Holiday")_ (2006) to become Meyer's third
highest-grossing project to date.[6]

For their performances, the cast was awarded a [National Board of Review of
Motion Pictures Award](/wiki/National_Board_of_Review_of_Motion_Pictures
"National Board of Review of Motion Pictures") for [Best Ensemble
Cast](/wiki/National_Board_of_Review_Award_for_Best_Cast#2010s "National Board
of Review Award for Best Cast") the same year. In addition, the film was
nominated at both the [Critics' Choice Awards](/wiki/Critics%27_Choice_Awards
"Critics' Choice Awards") and the [Satellite Awards](/wiki/Satellite_Awards
"Satellite Awards") and garnered Meyers two [Golden Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe
"Golden Globe") nominations, including [Best Motion Picture – Musical or
Comedy](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Motion_Picture_%E2%80%93_Musical_or_Comedy
"Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy") and [Best
Screenplay](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Screenplay "Golden Globe Award
for Best Screenplay"). Streep and Baldwin each were individually recognized
with [Best
Actress](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award_for_Best_Actress_%E2%80%93_Motion_Picture_Musical_or_Comedy
"Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy") and
[Best Supporting Actor](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actor_in_a_Supporting_Role
"BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Supporting Role") nominations at the Golden
Globe and [BAFTA](/wiki/BAFTA_Awards "BAFTA Awards") award ceremonies,
respectively.

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Complicated_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

Jane ([Meryl Streep](/wiki/Meryl_Streep "Meryl Streep")), who owns a
successful bakery in [Santa Barbara,
California](/wiki/Santa_Barbara,_California "Santa Barbara, California"), and
Jake Adler ([Alec Baldwin](/wiki/Alec_Baldwin "Alec Baldwin")), a successful
[attorney](/wiki/Attorney_at_law "Attorney at law"), divorced ten years
earlier. They had three children together, two girls and a boy, who are grown.
Jake, who was cheating on Jane, married the much younger Agness ([Lake
Bell](/wiki/Lake_Bell "Lake Bell")).

Jane and Jake attend their son Luke's graduation from college in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"). After a dinner together, the two
begin an affair, which continues in Santa Barbara. Jane is torn about the
affair; Jake is not. While Agness has Jake scheduled for regular sessions at a
fertility clinic, Jake is secretly taking medication to increase sperm count
for fertility, a side effect of which can cause dizziness. After one of his
sessions he has a lunchtime rendezvous with Jane at a hotel. Jake collapses in
the hotel room and a doctor is called. The doctor speculates that the reason
for Jake's distress may be the medication and says he should stop taking it.
Jake and Jane's children know nothing of the affair, but Harley ([John
Krasinski](/wiki/John_Krasinski "John Krasinski")), who is engaged to their
daughter Lauren, spots the pair and the doctor in the hotel, but keeps silent.

Adam ([Steve Martin](/wiki/Steve_Martin "Steve Martin")) is an
[architect](/wiki/Architect "Architect") hired to remodel Jane's home. Still
healing from a divorce of his own, he begins to fall in love with Jane. On the
night of Luke's graduation party in Santa Barbara, Jane invites Adam to the
party. She is stoned when he picks her up because she has smoked [a marijuana
joint](/wiki/Cannabis_\(drug\) "Cannabis \(drug\)") that Jake had given her
earlier. Before going into the party, Adam smokes some of the joint with Jane.
Once inside, they are laughing and happily high, Jake becomes jealous
observing them, and after pressing Jane, smokes some with her also.

Agness then observes Jake and Jane dancing together and realizes they are
having an affair. When they leave the party, Adam asks Jane if they could have
something to eat. Jane takes him to her bakery and they make chocolate
[croissants](/wiki/Croissants "Croissants") together. Jake and Agness
separate, although it is not clear who leaves whom. Eventually by a
[webcam](/wiki/Webcam "Webcam") in Jane's bedroom, Adam sees Jake naked and
realizes that the two have been having an affair. Adam tells Jane he cannot
continue seeing her because it will only lead to heartbreak. Jane's kids also
find out, and they are not happy about Mom and Dad getting together again
because they are still recovering from the divorce. Jane tells them she is not
getting back with Jake. Jane and Jake talk and end their affair on amicable
terms. The film ends with Adam at Jane's house ready to commence the
remodeling. Before the credits roll, Jane and Adam are seen laughing about the
chocolate croissants while walking into her house.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Complicated_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Complicated_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Casting")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Steve_Martin_2011.jpg/170px-
Steve_Martin_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Steve_Martin_2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Steve_Martin_2011.jpg "Enlarge")

_It 's Complicated_ marked [Steve Martin](/wiki/Steve_Martin "Steve Martin")'s
third collaboration with director [Nancy Meyers](/wiki/Nancy_Meyers "Nancy
Meyers").

In May 2008, [Nancy Meyers](/wiki/Nancy_Meyers "Nancy Meyers") agreed to a
project for [Universal Studios](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal Studios")
that she would write and direct, to be co-produced with [Scott
Rudin](/wiki/Scott_Rudin "Scott Rudin").[7] The project was referred to as
_The Untitled Nancy Meyers Project_ during its inception and early production.
Establishing commitments from the principals began in 2008, with [Meryl
Streep](/wiki/Meryl_Streep "Meryl Streep") and [Alec
Baldwin](/wiki/Alec_Baldwin "Alec Baldwin") entering discussions in
August,[8][9] and [Steve Martin](/wiki/Steve_Martin "Steve Martin") joining
the cast in October.[10] Casting continued through 2009, with [Zoe
Kazan](/wiki/Zoe_Kazan "Zoe Kazan"), [Lake Bell](/wiki/Lake_Bell "Lake Bell"),
and [Hunter Parrish](/wiki/Hunter_Parrish "Hunter Parrish") joining in
January,[11] [John Krasinski](/wiki/John_Krasinski "John Krasinski") in
February,[12] [Rita Wilson](/wiki/Rita_Wilson "Rita Wilson") in March,[13] and
Caitlin Fitzgerald in June.[14]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Complicated_\(film\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Filming")]

While the majority of the film is set in [Santa Barbara,
California](/wiki/Santa_Barbara,_California "Santa Barbara, California"), most
of the filming – including nearly all of the interiors – took place in [New
York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[15] Principal photography
began on February 18, 2009 at the Broadway Stages in the
[Brooklyn](/wiki/Brooklyn "Brooklyn") borough, where the interior scenes of
Jane's house were shot. Several other key locations were used during the first
portion of filming in New York, including Picnic House, a large, studio-sized
structure in Brooklyn's [Prospect Park](/wiki/Prospect_Park_\(Brooklyn\)
"Prospect Park \(Brooklyn\)"), where Jane's bakery was built inside; the
facilities at Sarabeth's Bakery in the [Chelsea Market](/wiki/Chelsea_Market
"Chelsea Market"); and a commercial loft building in New York's [Chelsea
district](/wiki/Chelsea,_Manhattan "Chelsea, Manhattan"), where scenes at
Adam's architecture office were filmed in.[15] As Martin was soon to embark on
a concert tour to promote _[The Crow: New Songs for the Five-String
Banjo](/wiki/The_Crow:_New_Songs_for_the_Five-String_Banjo "The Crow: New
Songs for the Five-String Banjo")_ (2009), his schedule required the team to
complete shooting his scenes during the first two months of filming.[15]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Santa_Barbara_County_Courthouse.jpg/240px-
Santa_Barbara_County_Courthouse.jpg)](/wiki/File:Santa_Barbara_County_Courthouse.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Santa_Barbara_County_Courthouse.jpg "Enlarge")

Though set in [Santa Barbara](/wiki/Santa_Barbara,_California "Santa Barbara,
California"), the film was primarily shot in [New York
City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[15]

In April 2009, the company relocated to [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los
Angeles"), where cast and crew started filming scenes taking place outside
Jane's house, for which a ranch house located in [Thousand
Oaks](/wiki/Thousand_Oaks "Thousand Oaks") in the north of Los Angeles was
used.[15] In mid-April, the crew spent a few days filming exteriors in
[Montecito](/wiki/Montecito,_California "Montecito, California") and [Santa
Barbara](/wiki/Santa_Barbara,_California "Santa Barbara, California") – just
days before [wildfires](/wiki/Wildfire "Wildfire") took a heavy toll on the
area.[15] Additional scenes were taken in front of numerous downtown
landmarks, including the [Santa Barbara County
Courthouse](/wiki/Santa_Barbara_County_Courthouse "Santa Barbara County
Courthouse") and the [El Paseo](/wiki/El_Paseo_\(Santa_Barbara,_California\)
"El Paseo \(Santa Barbara, California\)") section.[15] Afterwards, the team
returned to Los Angeles for completion of the scenes at Jane's house and for
the filming at the Bel-Air Bay Club in the [Pacific
Palisades](/wiki/Pacific_Palisades,_Los_Angeles "Pacific Palisades, Los
Angeles") neighborhood.[15] In early May, principal photography returned to
Brooklyn for completion.[15] For Luke's graduation scenes, shooting took place
at [St. John's University](/wiki/St._John%27s_University_\(New_York\) "St.
John's University \(New York\)") in [Queens](/wiki/Queens "Queens") and on
[Park Avenue](/wiki/Park_Avenue "Park Avenue") in [Manhattan](/wiki/Manhattan
"Manhattan").[15] Several different locations stood in for the fictional Park
Regent hotel: While a [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")-owned
residence building on Park Avenue and [59th
Street](/wiki/59th_Street_\(Manhattan\) "59th Street \(Manhattan\)") was used
for exterior shots, the lobby and Jane's hotel room were in the [JW Marriott
Essex House](/wiki/JW_Marriott_Essex_House "JW Marriott Essex House"). The
hotel bar was the interior of a restaurant on [Tenth
Avenue](/wiki/Tenth_Avenue_\(Manhattan\) "Tenth Avenue \(Manhattan\)").[15]
Filming eventually completed in August 2009.[16]

The sets were easy to design. Most scenes take place in the protagonist's home
and interior courtyard, and as such the architectural details had to be
fastidiously worked out, but the rooms were kept bare to reflect the
character's functional tastes and limited budget. There are relatively few
decorations, just "a bunch of thrift-store things haphazardly thrown
together", in the words of production designer [Jon Hutman](/wiki/Jon_Hutman
"Jon Hutman"). The building itself is a traditional 1920s Spanish-ranch-style
adobe-mud house which "epitomised the Santa Barbara area."[17]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Complicated_\(film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Complicated_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Critical response")]

_It 's Complicated_ received mixed reviews from film critics. Review
aggregation website [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes")
gave the film a rating of 57% based on 172 reviews, with an
[average](/wiki/Average "Average") score of 5.8/10. According to the website,
the critical consensus is: "Despite fine work by an appealing cast, _It 's
Complicated_ is predictable romantic comedy fare, going for broad laughs
instead of subtlety and nuance."[18] Another review aggregator,
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), which assigns a [weighted
average](/wiki/Weighted_average "Weighted average"), gave the film a score of
57 out of 100, based on 30 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".[19]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Alec_Baldwin%2C_Meryl_Streep_15th_Annual_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards.jpg/260px-
Alec_Baldwin%2C_Meryl_Streep_15th_Annual_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards.jpg)](/wiki/File:Alec_Baldwin,_Meryl_Streep_15th_Annual_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Alec_Baldwin,_Meryl_Streep_15th_Annual_Screen_Actors_Guild_Awards.jpg
"Enlarge")

Baldwin and Streep received generally positive reviews from critics for their
performances in _It 's Complicated_.[20]

[Wesley Morris](/wiki/Wesley_Morris "Wesley Morris") of the _[Boston
Globe](/wiki/Boston_Globe "Boston Globe")_ called the film "the most
emotionally sophisticated of all Meyers’s fantasies" and praised the acting
performances in it. He noted that the film felt like "a made-for-Meryl film
[in which] Streep deploys all her best moves [...] in movie star mode, and
she’s irresistible," and declared Baldwin a worthy match to her, writing:
"_It’s Complicated_ unleashes an unabashedly, desperately romantic side of
Baldwin that we haven’t seen before. He doesn’t steal this movie so much as
grant all Streep’s fluttering and twirling and hand-fanning an exuberant
counterweight."[20] In his review for the _[Washington
Post](/wiki/Washington_Post "Washington Post")_ , [Michael
O'Sullivan](/w/index.php?title=Michael_O%27Sullivan_\(critic\)&action=edit&redlink=1
"Michael O'Sullivan \(critic\) \(page does not exist\)") called the film a
"very grown-up – and very funny – love story [which] manages to be both light
on its feet and heavy enough to deliver something of a message." He concluded:
"Food Network porn, hot, middle-age sex and a happy, if slightly bittersweet,
ending. For a particular audience – but not just for that audience – what's
not to love?"[20] [Peter Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") of
_[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ called the film an
"unapologetic chick flick" and wrote that "you don't have to feel guilty for
lapping up this froth. Just don't expect nourishment." He rated the film two
and a half stars out of four.[21]

[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") of the _[Chicago Sun-
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ also gave it the same
rating and called the film a prime example of Meyer's established "cottage
industry of movies about romantically inclined middle-aged people." He found
praise for the cast of both Baldwin and Streep, the latter of which he felt
"inspires as so often our belief that she's good at everything she does," but
noted that while the film contained "funny stuff" and likeable characters, _It
's Complicated_ was more of "a rearrangement of the goods in Nancy Meyers'
bakery, and some of them belong on the day-old shelf."[22] Writing for
_[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ magazine, Mary Pols
complimented Streep's "radiant, funny and endearingly vulnerable" performance
and Meyers' "clever and fresh [...] intent in showing the reality of the
fantasy coming true." She, however, felt that _It 's Complicated_ "is
positioned more as a which-guy-will-she-choose story" which misses "dramatic
tension to feed that plot line."[23]

[Lisa Schwarzbaum](/wiki/Lisa_Schwarzbaum "Lisa Schwarzbaum") of
_[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_
gave the film a B- rating and declared the film a "middle-aged porn, the
specialty of Meyers, who also set ladies and interior decorators drooling over
homes and gardens in 2006's _The Holiday_."[24] [Lou
Lumenick](/wiki/Lou_Lumenick "Lou Lumenick") from _[New York
Post](/wiki/New_York_Post "New York Post")_ stated that it "coulda had more
laughs, but in the spirit of seasonal good cheer, let me predict that the
best-chocolate-croissant-making montage in Hollywood history is going to help
this one clean up at the box office." He found that Martin seemed
"uncomfortable in his thankless role," while "Streep and Baldwin, though, seem
to be thoroughly enjoying themselves" and compared the film to [Noël
Coward](/wiki/No%C3%ABl_Coward "Noël Coward")'s classic farce _[Private
Lives](/wiki/Private_Lives "Private Lives")_.[25] [Salon.com](/wiki/Salon.com
"Salon.com") writer Stephanie Zacharek dismissed the film as "another missive
from romantic-comedy hell," and felt that "Alec Baldwin -- in his undershorts,
no less -- saves Nancy Meyers' latest midlife whingefest."[26]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=It%27s_Complicated_\(film\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Box office")]

Released on December 25, 2009 in the United States,[27][28] the film opened in
2,887 locations and placed fourth on the US box office after its first
weekend. It charted behind _[Avatar](/wiki/Avatar_\(2009_film\) "Avatar \(2009
film\)")_ , _[Sherlock Holmes](/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes_\(2009_film\) "Sherlock
Holmes \(2009 film\)")_ , and _[Alvin and the Chipmunks: The
Squeakquel](/wiki/Alvin_and_the_Chipmunks:_The_Squeakquel "Alvin and the
Chipmunks: The Squeakquel")_ with $22,100,820, scoring a $7,655 average income
per theatre. It played well through the holidays and into January 2010,
ultimately closing on April 1 with $112.7 million in North America and a total
of $214,727,200 worldwide.[3]
